instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.P5VS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS3_PGOOD? P5VS3_PGOOD indicates that the PP5V_S3 power rail is functioning properly..
definitions.P3V3S5_PGOOD: What is P3V3S5_PGOOD? P3V3S5_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP3V3_S5 power rail is working..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.CPUIMVP_PGOOD: What is CPUIMVP_PGOOD? CPUIMVP_PGOOD is a signal from the CPU VCORE buck converter IC that indicates CPU power is good which is necessary to create PM_S0_PGOOD..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
Hi 

i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in an S0 state.  but no fan spin.

The missing S0 rails are
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>


incidentally <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCD</SIGNAL> is at 1.35v and not 1.5v

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is not present (50mv)

I have changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> twice just in case

inputs on <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> are

<SIGNAL>VMON_Q2_BASE</SIGNAL> 1.06v
<SIGNAL>VMON_Q3_BASE</SIGNAL>  1.3v
<SIGNAL>VMON_Q4_BASE</SIGNAL>  0.7v
S0PGD 0.65v

the voltages coming in to each of the resistors (and dividers) feeding <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> are fine.  the resistors themselves are fine. and the <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> resistors also seem fine

any thoughts on where to go next with this board?  

thanks

justin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
If you have doubts with <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>, remove it.
The board should work without it.
If <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> stays low, VCORE will not appear.
So check wich power supply involved in generating <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> fails.
Check first if <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> gets 3V at pin1.
Next, remove one by one <RESISTOR>R7901</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>-66.
When <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high, you just found the culprit...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
thank you

removing <RESISTOR>R7901</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7903</RESISTOR>-6 sends pwrgd high.  measuring on the incoming side of each removed resistor pad gives the following:

<SIGNAL>P5VS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>  0.5v
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 0.5v
<SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 0v
cpuvccios0_pggod  0.6v
<SIGNAL>P1V8S0_PGGOD</SIGNAL> 0.6v
CPUIMVPAXG_PGOOD 0v

so i guess a problem on one of the 0v lines....  any known issues to look for on those?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7903</RESISTOR>-6"
???

You must check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> after each resistor removed.
You cannot get 3V on the other side of the resistors, as the pull-up <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> remains on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> side...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
for example leave <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR> in place; remove the other resistors 7963-8 and test for voltage on pad 1.

unfortunately now a retrograde step in any event. i had identified that CPUVCCIOS0_EN was not present. went to make a cup of tea and have come back to find that the board is no longer in an s0 state. so I have lost most of the rails. I still have the hot rails but <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 2.7v.

no orange light on the charger.

damn.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: Check now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 rails...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: i have all the always on rails.just RTC is at 2.7v rather than 3v. i will replace the clock chip\

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: Good luck, I hope PCH is still OK...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
that would be annoying.  but I can't see why the PCH would spontaneously have fried.  

I have swapped the clock chip. Output on RTC is still 2.7v . Also <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is at 2.7v as is the <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> line coming from <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> 

no enable on <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>.  dead SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
"I can't see why the PCH would spontaneously have fried
---------------------------------
i had identified that CPUVCCIOS0_EN was not present"
You already have something PCH related...

Check resistance to ground on VCCRTC and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> lines; be aware, both go to PCH.
Compare with a good board, if possible.
Also check again all RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
I don't think it can be PCH as that enable signal is generated from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R</SIGNAL> which is also required for other enable lines that I know are functional. 

i guess either r or <CAPACITOR>C7981</CAPACITOR> must have been damaged.

But of course now the problem is rather wider with no full S5 rails and only 2.7v on pp3v3.  I will check the resistances tomorrow morning before work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
I don't want to dissapoint you, but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is controlled by PCH; it also has the pull-up resistor inside.
All the sleep signals are controlled by PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: Sure. But if the signal wasn't being generated then all the other rails that rely on it would not be present.   And previously the board was in an S0 state meaning that <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> was not in an active low state .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
You're right, it "WAS"...
So you can't discard PCH now.
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03 are prone to fail on this board.
But them cannot drop so much VRTC rail.

If <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> receives correct 3V42, and all caps from VRTC are good (disconnect them for test), then no other reason than bad PCH remains...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
resistances on the requested lines are
PPVRTC- 4MOhm
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.8kOhm

the always-on rails are present (save that PPVRTC is at 2.7v)

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>,<SIGNAL>SMS_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> are both high.
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is at at a few mV.  

dead SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
"If <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> receives correct 3V42, and all caps from VRTC are good (disconnect them for test), then no other reason than bad PCH remains..."
Did you check???

PCH can have high resistance to ground, but it can enter in some kind of avalanche effect, droping VRTC...
No matters SMC is good or not.
Bad RTC block will not allow PCH starting power on sequence!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
i used an RTC from a donor board.  but since VRTC is the same as <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> I suspect the issue is not the clock chip but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.  

i will double check the caps.  

the more interesting question, forensically, is that the board had fan spin when the resistor to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> was remove to prevent it pulling low.  The heat sink was in place and, as said, fan spinning happily and normally.  It then spontaneously stopped within the next twenty minutes.  No apparent overheating (although I was not present).  No evident corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
PCH should work with 2.7V on VRTC.
The suspect thing is if that voltage arrives to PCH as is, or is pulled down by PCH...

Do you also have 2.7V at <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> coil?
If yes, check corresponding power supply.
Pay atention to feedback resistors, <RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR>/61.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
yes.  with L7260 removed there is 2.6+v at both pads (which I find a bit odd and makes me suspicious of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>) 

Interestingly <RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR> and61 measure 11k and 7.8k respectievely . on a donor board they measure closer to 20 and 9k

replaced the clock chip again.  ppvrtc is at 2.3v now.  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> remains the same. I'm not getting a 32kHz signal on the clock chip though. starts at 16kHz and then spirals down to 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
also to note that there is no 3v on the middle pin of the magsafe.

<CHIP>U2700</CHIP> receives <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.  i cannot see any cap that is bad around <CHIP>U2700</CHIP>.  there is no short on that rail.  

But ... i cannot see the logic that says that the PCH must start up just because <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> is working.   doesn't the PCH need <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> AND (<CHIP>U2750</CHIP>)  <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PGOOD</SIGNAL> AND (<CHIP>U2760</CHIP>) <SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRG</SIGNAL> to start up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
Mentioned signals appear much later...
PCH should first release <SIGNAL>SLP_SUS</SIGNAL> and next <SIGNAL>SLP_SX</SIGNAL>, after got PWRBTN reaction from SMC.

"with L7260 removed there is 2.6+v at both pads"
What???
The coil is a part (important) of buck controller!!!
Any voltage measure without coil is a non-sense...

Change <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>; pay atention to R/<CAPACITOR>C7264</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: Yes - it's very odd. the voltage stays the same whether the coil is there or not.  makes me very suspicious of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.  but .... there is no enable inputer on <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> either

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>

mostly at or close to 0mv except for
3 80mv
10 20mv
16 800mv
17 2.7v
18 2.7
22 3.3v
23 8.2v
24 2.7v
25 2.7v
26 2.47v

<CHIP>U7941</CHIP>
1 3.42v
2 0
3 0
4 3.39v

6 2.7v
7 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
As expected, missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. It comes from SMC.
You didn't mention incorrect <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> before...

Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> value.
Also try a reflow to SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
why do you think that PPBUS is incorrect?  It is 8.2v.  

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high (as per message yesterday). 

yes.  missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> as per the same previous message.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> correct value is aprox 8.4-8.5V.
8.2V means SMC don't talk with <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>!
And this be caused by SMC, or <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, or something else connected on SMBattery Bus.
As you also miss <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, SMC is first suspect here.
The best option is change it. But I recommend to reball it first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
ah. that is interesting.  PPBus has always been 8.2v even when the board was in an S0 state.  definitely something fishy.

i will reflow the SMC later.  I don't have any stencils here to do a proper reball of a donor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
I did many at hand; there are aprox 150 balls, not too many...
0.35-0.4mm for commodity, but you can also use 0.3, even 0.45mm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message:
ha.  it is a plan ... but i am rather middle aged and have shaky hands!  

i may try with some old donor boards one weekend!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: reflowing the SMC did not work by the way.  I will debug a bit more later.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no fan spin
threads.message: Don't be afraid, I'm also middle age and work with one eye only...
